In the Beta Sigma Tau story on Page one, the former president of the now defunct JIIU chapter of the inter-racial, interreligious fraternity expresses the feeling that one .of the causes
for hi group failing* here may have been that Hopkins is not
"yet quite ready."
This is somewhat of a provocative stateMent implying that
the Hopkins does not "yet" have what it has long been reputed
to possess—a traditionally liberal atmosphere. Although it is admitted that the group's difficulty was ,mainly "internal," the
former chapter president nevertheless labels BST's reception
by the other campus fraternities as one of "coldness." Could it
be that on this long reputed "liberal" campus liberal social
groups can not be integrated?
*Unlike the inter-racial, inter-religious nature of Beta Sigma
Tau, the 12 existing Hopkins fraternities are divided into two
segments: three fraternities "Jewish," nine "gentile." In the
IFB, according to the president, there is an agreement of nebulous
origin restricting each segment in each year's initial freshman
rushing period to rush only freshmen of its own predominant
faith, either Jewish or Christian. Of the nine gentile fraternities,
two have clauses restricting membership to "white, Christian
males." Of these two, one has a further restriction limiting
membership to "citizens of the United States." Seven of the
"gentile" fraternities have no restrictive membership clauses in
their national constitutions; however, in many instances policies
of these fraternities on the national level have had virtually
the same effect as restrictive membership clauses would have had.
